snippet: In the 1850's, when the gold rush was in full swing, a daguerreotype artist posted this notice to the babies of San Francisco:    ''Dear Little Creatures: You have the good fortune to commence life in an age of progress and improvement; you enjoy ...
lead_paragraph: In the 1850's, when the gold rush was in full swing, a daguerreotype artist posted this notice to the babies of San Francisco: ''Dear Little Creatures: You have the good fortune to commence life in an age of progress and improvement; you enjoy privileges which your ancestors knew nothing of, not the least of which is the facility for transferring your interesting countenances to a glass or silver plate.'' The studio charged $3 for a portrait of a child, ''a trifling expense considering the satisfaction it will be to look at your infantile likenesses after you grow up to be men and women, or, if you should die in infancy, to be kept as a valuable memento by surviving relatives.''
abstract: Sarah Boxer reviews traveling photography exhibition Silver and Gold: Cased Images of the California Gold Rush, currently on view at Oakland Museum of California; show consists of unsung, unsigned daguerrotypes, portraits of diverse personalities of miners caught up in Gold Rush; photos (M)

headline.main: The 49ers Didn't Know The Gold Was In the Photos
